steps.title: Consider machine washing them.
steps.content: Consider machine washing them. [1] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020. Cotton is one of the most common slipper materials. Just like cotton clothing, all cotton slippers will be washing machine safe. [2] X Research source Use warm (not hot) to make sure you don’t shrink the slippers. Use a gentle cycle that won’t bang them out of shape. [3] X Research source If you want to toss them in with the regular wash, use a washing machine bag like you’d use for a sweater. [4] X Research source Use a low heat setting to dry. You can also allow them to air dry. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Fill your sink with warm, soapy water.
steps.content: Fill your sink with warm, soapy water. If you don’t want to risk machine washing those slippers, then you can hand wash cotton slippers. [6] X Research source Use a stopper and fill your sink with warm, soapy water. A small dose of a mild laundry detergent will do. [7] X Research source Hand-washing detergents will instruct you how much to use.

steps.title: Drop the slippers in and agitate them.
steps.content: Drop the slippers in and agitate them. You want to make sure that the soapy water saturates the material. Use your fingers or a gentle cloth to scrub the inside lining to penetrate the grime. [8] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020.

steps.title: Let them sit.
steps.content: Let them sit. The soap solution won’t hurt the cotton. Give the slippers a good ten minutes to soak after you give them the mild scrub. [9] X Research source You’ll see the soapy water changing colors as it leaches out all the funk.

steps.title: Rinse the slippers.
steps.content: Rinse the slippers. After the slippers have soaked, go ahead and let the water out of the sink. Turn the faucet on at about the same warm setting as before and give the slippers a thorough rinse. [10] X Research source Squish the slippers as you rinse like you would to get excess soap out of a sponge or luffa. You can refill the sink with clean water to rinse them. Let them soak for ten minutes. You can also rinse them under the running faucet for two or three minutes to get all the soap out.

steps.title: Remove the excess water.
steps.content: Remove the excess water. Don’t actually wring the slippers. This can misshape them. Instead, press down on them at several points to remove the excess water. [11] X Research source You can also squeeze them in a towel to absorb the excess water. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Let them dry.
steps.content: Let them dry. Set the slippers aside to air dry. [13] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020. You can also use a warm setting on a blowdryer to dry them out. [14] X Research source A blowdryer will also fluff the soft, cottony insides of the slippers.

steps.title: Wipe with a towel.
steps.content: Wipe with a towel. You cannot machine wash or hand wash suede slippers by submerging them. If you spill something on the suede, use a clean towel to blot and wipe at the spill. If the suede is waterproof, then you can use a damp towel to wipe at the spill. If not, stick with a dry towel.

steps.title: Use a suede cleaning kit.
steps.content: Use a suede cleaning kit. [15] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020. If the spill can stain the suede and you know the towel treatment alone will not suffice, then use a suede cleaning kit on the exterior. A suede cleaning kit will come with a stain eraser and a small, stiff suede brush with which to work in the eraser. A suede brush, nail file, or soft-textured sandpaper can also remove mud or scuff marks. This will also return the nap texture to the suede. Once the exterior of the slippers is clean, consider applying a suede-safe waterproofing spray to make cleaning them easier in the future.

steps.title: Use a baby wipe on the interior.
steps.content: Use a baby wipe on the interior. Baby wipes allow you to scrub out the slippers without wetting the suede. This works for both cotton and fleece-lined interiors. Baby wipes are low in moisture and have a mild detergent. [16] X Research source Use a couple of them to work the inside of the slippers until you stop seeing the grime staining them. You can alternatively dampen a washcloth and dab just a drop or two of wool detergent or another mild soap such as baby shampoo on the washcloth before using it to scrub the soft insides of the slippers. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Use a clean damp washcloth to wipe out the detergent.
steps.content: Use a clean damp washcloth to wipe out the detergent. Once cleaned out, use a clean, damp washcloth to wipe out the insides. Remove any leftover detergent. Baby wipes are mild enough that this might not be necessary, but it will be if you use the couple drops of wool detergent or baby shampoo. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Allow them to air dry.
steps.content: Allow them to air dry. You do not want to apply heat to suede slippers, so you’ll simply have to give them plenty of time to air dry before you wear them again. [19] X Expert Source Marc Sigal Shoe Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 January 2020. Wads of newspaper are actually a great way to absorb moisture without using heat, so you can stuff the insides with balled up newspaper to help dry them out more quickly.

steps.title: Use a leather-safe soap.
steps.content: Use a leather-safe soap. You should only treat the exteriors with products designed for leather shoes. This includes non-enzyme liquid soaps designed for leather products. You can use the same leather shoe cleaner you would use on other leather shoes to remove dirt and scuffs. If the insides of the slippers are leather, use the same process to clean the interior.

steps.title: Shine them with a soft, cotton cloth.
steps.content: Shine them with a soft, cotton cloth. After cleaning them with a leather cleaner, let them sit for approximately five minutes. Then shine the slippers with a clean, soft, cotton cloth.

steps.title: Apply a leather shoe conditioner.
steps.content: Apply a leather shoe conditioner. To keep leather slippers soft and moisturized, apply a leather shoe conditioner after cleaning. The leather will absorb a natural conditioner easier than synthetic ones. Apply the conditioner as directed to help them age better.

steps.title: Use baby wipes to clean out the insides of the slippers.
steps.content: Use baby wipes to clean out the insides of the slippers. For fleece-lined slippers, use the same process as with fleece-lined suede slippers. Namely, baby wipes, which are low in moisture and contain a mild detergent. [20] X Research source Use a couple of baby wipes to scrub out the inside of each slipper until the wipe is no longer discoloring from the grime. You can alternatively use a mildly damp washcloth with just one or two drops of wool detergent or baby shampoo to scrub out the insides of the slippers. This method requires using a second damp washcloth to remove any excess soap afterward.

steps.title: Allow the slippers to air dry.
steps.content: Allow the slippers to air dry. You don’t want to apply heat to leather slippers. You will need to give them time to air dry. As with the suede slippers, you can use a wad of newspaper inside the slipper to help draw the excess moisture out of the lining, which will hasten the drying process a bit.
